solution_01_data_basics/02_proportion/02_list_proportion_between_v1

video

First, it helps to sort the data. \[\text{sort}(\mathbf{x}) = 81, 82, 83, 83, 84, 85, 85, 87, 88, 88\]

You could use R to sort the data:

sort(c(88,85,87,82,81,85,84,83,88,83))
##  [1] 81 82 83 83 84 85 85 87 88 88

You could also use a spreadsheet. Import the table into a spreadsheet. Then, highlight the column of measurements and use Sort function.


  1. (ANS=0.3) The proportion of measurements between 85.5 and 88.5 is 0.3. \[\text{prop}[85.5<\mathbf{x}<88.5]=0.3\]
  2. (ANS=0.7) The proportion of measurements outside 84.5 and 87.5 is 0.7. \[\text{prop}[\texttt{NOT}(84.5<\mathbf{x}<87.5)]=0.7\]
  3. (ANS=0.9) The proportion of measurements closer than 3.5 cm from 85 cm is 0.9. \[\text{prop}\left[\big|\mathbf{x}-85\big|<3.5\right] = 0.9\]
  4. (ANS=0.5) The proportion of measurements farther than 1.5 cm from 84 cm is 0.5. \[\text{prop}\left[\big|\mathbf{x}-84\big|>1.5\right] = 0.5\]
  5. (ANS=3.5) You can guess and check until you find a half-integer that satisfies the equation. It turns out that \(r = 3.5\) satisfies the equation, because \[\text{prop}\left[\big|\mathbf{x}-85\big|<3.5\right] ~=~ 0.9\]
  6. (ANS=0.5) You can guess and check until you find a half-integer that satisfies the equation. It turns out that \(r = 0.5\) satisfies the equation, because \[\text{prop}\left[\big|\mathbf{x}-81\big|>0.5\right] ~=~ 0.9\]
